questions.text: A 55- year- old female patient presents with a breast mass of size 2 cm in diameter with palpable ipsilateral two axillary lymph nodes and no evidence of distant metastases. Which TNM classification suits the patient best?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

T1cN1M0 The patient has a tumour of 2 cm or 20 mm in size. There are palpable axillary lymph nodes on both sides & no Metastasis . This accounts for T1cN1M0 in TNM classification for breast cancer . T1a includes tumours >1 mm but ≤ 5 mm. T1b includes Tumour >5 mm but ≤ 10 mm in the most significant dimension. T1c has Tumour >10 mm but ≤ 20 mm in the most important size. T2 includes tumours >20 mm but ≤ 50 mm to the most considerable extent. With the only available clinical data, it is possible to make only clinical N staging. The explanation given here is for pathological N staging. N0 includes no regional lymph nodes. N1 has micrometastases or metastases in mobile ipsilateral level I, II axillary lymph nodes. N2a includes metastasis in fixed or matted ipsilateral group I, II axillary lymph nodes. N2b includes metastasis only in clinically apparent ipsilateral internal mammary lymph nodes without clinically evident axillary lymph node metastasis. N3a includes metastasis in ipsilateral infraclavicular lymph nodes. N3b has metastasis in ipsilateral internal mammary lymph nodes and axillary lymph nodes, and N3c includes metastasis in ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes. M0 indicates no metastasis, while M1 suggests the presence of distant metastasis.

Highyeild:

The TNM classification system is an important tool to describe the extent of cancer in a patient. It helps in determining the prognosis and in planning treatment. The T category of TNM classification describes the size of the tumor . In this case, the tumor size is 2 cm, which falls under the T1 category. The N category of TNM classification describes the extent of spread to nearby lymph nodes . The presence of palpable ipsilateral two axillary lymph nodes indicates that the cancer has spread to regional lymph nodes, and hence the N category is N1. The M category of TNM classification describes the presence or absence of distant metastases. In this case, there is no evidence of distant metastases, and hence the M category is M0.

Extraedge:

TNM classification system is not the only factor that determines the prognosis and treatment plan for a patient with breast cancer. Other factors, such as the histological type of the cancer, the grade of the tumor, and the patient's overall health , also play a role.

questions.text: A 43-year-old female on mammography showed a dense ovoid opacity of 14 mm with irregular, suspicious microcalcifications on the right breast. A suspect galactophorous dilatation of the right superior-external quadrant was seen by ultrasound. Bilateral radical surgery was performed, and Histology concluded a high-grade DCIS of 40 mm × 35 mm × 25 mm with central foci extending to the main galactophorous ducts associated with Paget’s disease. The sentinel lymph node was negative. Which of the following staging suits the patient best?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tis Tis denotes Carcinoma in situ – DCIS/ or Paget disease of the nipple. T1 includes Tumours ≤ 20 mm in the most significant dimension. T2 has Tumour >20 mm but ≤50 mm in greatest dimension. T3 Tumour includes >50 mm in most-significant size. Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is a benign entity removed from TNM staging in the AJCC Cancer Staging Manual, 8th edition.

Highyeild:

Tis refers to carcinoma in situ, meaning the cancer is confined to the ducts or lobules and has not invaded the surrounding breast tissue. Tis is a non-invasive stage of breast cancer and is sometimes referred to as pre-cancerous because it has not yet spread to other parts of the body. In breast cancer, Tis refers specifically to ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) , which is a non-invasive cancer that develops in the milk ducts. DCIS cells are abnormal and can become cancerous if they invade the surrounding tissue. However, when DCIS is confined to the ducts, it is considered a pre-cancerous condition.

Extraedge:

Tis staging is important because it helps to determine the appropriate treatment for breast cancer patients. Treatment options for Tis stage breast cancer typically include surgery, radiation therapy, and/or hormone therapy. It is important to note that even though Tis stage breast cancer is non-invasive, it can still develop into invasive breast cancer if left untreated. Therefore, early detection and treatment is key to successful outcomes in breast cancer patients.
